p: The aim of this proposed framework is to aid in assessing whether adaptation targets current inequities and determinants of health that may reduce unequally distributed health outcomes. To evaluate health-related climate change adaptation for its climate justice contribution, the theoretical framework draws from two main concepts: (i) health inequity [ 48, 49, 50] and (ii) resilience to climatic changes [ 51, 52]. In more detail, these two concepts can be illustrated using seven domains ( Figure 1), which illustrate variables and contents with which to measure possible climate justice advancement. Susan Cutter et al. [ 53] describe six of these domains which are relevant to disaster resilience: social, economic, infrastructure, institutional, community, and environmental domains. As current research shows that culture can limit or facilitate “opportunities to become healthier” [ 54], we propose adding culture as a further domain. Together, these seven domainns cover the range of likely determinants of human health potentially affected by climate change. They serve as the overarching evaluation frame. Table 1 supplements this framework by providing an overview over possible operational indicators for each area (adapted from [ 6, 53, 54]).
